subject: Re: [junit] How to enforce the executing order of *Test.class?
msgSnippet: xsli2, Thanks for a good question.  JUnit, and many tools based on it, are not designed to make it easy to specify the order in which tests are run.  There may
messageBody:
xsli2,

Thanks for a good question. JUnit, and many tools based on it, are not
designed to make it easy to specify the order in which tests are run. There
may be a way to do what you want, but is there any way to make it so that
secondTest and firstTest could be executed in either order? Or you could
make an explicit TestSuite (If you're using JUnit 3) or Suite (in JUnit 4)
in the order you want.

Good luck,

David Saff

On 4/17/07, xsli2 <xsli2@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
>
> I am doing junit testing using build.xml and ant. Within build.xml,
> there are several targets. If I test individual target, all pass
> successfully:
>
> >ant target1 //passes
>
> >ant target2 //passes
>
> >... //all passes
>
> But, if I just do:
>
> >ant test //testing all targets and it fails
>
> I believe it fails because the *Test.class are executed in a random
> sequence. But in target1, there are two Java classes, secondTest.class
> can only be executed after firstTest.class. "ant target1" will force
> such an order and it passes successfully. "ant test" will not
> guarantee it so most of time fails. I posted target1 and test part
> within build.xml. I have tried using fork as you can see below. I am
> very new to junit. I cannot do it right.
>
> Thank you very much for your help.
>
>
>
> <part of build.xml>
> ...
> <target name="target1" depends="compile-test, prepare-test">
> <delete dir="${test.xml.dir}"/>
> <mkdir dir="${test.xml.dir}"/>
> <junit errorProperty="test.failed"
> failureProperty="test.failed" fork="yes">
>
> <sysproperty key="testfilesdir"
> value="${testfiles.dir}"/>
> <classpath refid="project.classpath"/>
> <formatter type="brief" usefile="false"/>
> <formatter type="xml"/>
> <batchtest todir="${test.xml.dir}" fork="yes">
> <fileset dir="${build.test.dir}"
> includes="**/firstTest.class"/>
> </batchtest>
> </junit>
> <copy file="testoutput/tci.xml"
> tofile="testoutput/tci.xml.part1"/>
> <junit errorProperty="test.failed"
> failureProperty="test.failed" fork="yes">
> <sysproperty key="testfilesdir"
> value="${testfiles.dir}"/>
> <classpath refid="project.classpath"/>
> <formatter type="brief" usefile="false"/>
> <formatter type="xml"/>
> <batchtest todir="${test.xml.dir}" fork="yes">
> <fileset dir="${build.test.dir}"
> includes="**/secondTest.class"/>
> </batchtest>
> </junit>
> <copy file="testoutput/tci.xml"
> tofile="testoutput/tci.xml.part2"/>
> <fail if="test.failed" message="Build failed because
> some test(s) failed."/>
> </target>
>
> <target name="test" depends="compile-test, prepare-test" >
> <delete dir="${test.xml.dir}"/>
> <mkdir dir="${test.xml.dir}"/>
> <junit errorProperty="test.failed"
> failureProperty="test.failed" fork="on">
>
> <sysproperty key="testfilesdir"
> value="${testfiles.dir}"/>
>
> <env key="LD_LIBRARY_PATH"
> value="${env.LD_LIBRARY_PATH}:${vendor.lib.dir}"/>
>
> <classpath refid="project.classpath"/>
> <formatter type="brief" usefile="false"/>
> <formatter type="xml"/>
> <batchtest todir="${test.xml.dir}" fork="yes">
> <fileset dir="${build.test.dir}"
> includes="**/*Test.class"/>
> </batchtest>
> </junit>
> <fail if="test.failed" message="Build failed because
> some test(s) failed."/>
> </target>
>
> </part of build.xml>
